item.description:
This week we're heading to new waters...

hopefully, none of the trails are over our heads.

[I'm moving the date to the 12th, because after today's rains, we just might find ourselves, quite literally, above our heads...]

The Ride
I'm expecting similar trails to Arcadia, yet with somewhat different currents. From what I understand, Big River has the same combination of fire roads and single-track, passing through forests and fields, over varied terrain, from smooth to rough, over rocks and roots, gravel and dirt (which will require a bit of technical skill), but the difference being these trails grew up around mountain biking, and because of that, I look forward to trails designed with that in mind. As always, there should be no worries, because we will be following The Unwritten Primary Rules of Group Mountain Bike Riding: 1. We ride as a group; 2. We hike what we cannot ride; and 3. We wait at all major trailheads. Our pace will be moderate and accommodating (no speedsters here), but you should know that the ride is filled with a number of short steep up and downs, and I ask that you believe yourself to be an intermediately skilled rider, or a fit beginner/intermediate rider willing to be challenged by the terrain. I will be riding a rigid single-speed (no shocks) w/ flat pedals, so my pace will not be blazing, nor will I be riding up every climb (I blame the single-speed); that my friends (the riding up every climb) is for another time.

PS: Please take note of the meet time. Plan to meet at 5:15 so that we can begin our ride close to 5:30; this will hopefully keep us from riding out, in the dark.


Directions:
Take Exit 7 off of Route 95, bear left (for those coming from the north) or right (for those coming from the south), and head south on New London Tpke for 200 - 400 feet. Turn right into the Park and Ride, park... and ride.
